awd_titl_txt: Constraining the Relationship Between Vegetation Change and Net Carbon Sequestration in Arctic and Boreal Peatlands
awd_abstract_narration:
Peat-forming ecosystems are key components of the global carbon cycle, as they are tremendous stores of carbon from carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. But peatlands also release methane back to the atmosphere. The degree to which peatlands act as carbon sinks and methane sources largely depends on the types of plants growing there. The far northern areas where Arctic peatlands occur are warming rapidly and so it is important to determine how sensitive their carbon storages are to changes in vegetation that are already underway. It is known that when the main peatland plants change from sphagnum mosses to sedges, as is happening in many areas, the rate of carbon storage may change a lot, but the specific response of any particular peatland is not easy to predict. Much of the unpredictability results from difficulties in telling apart the dominant plants in peatlands through history. If that was possible, then much better predictions into the future could be made. So the main objective of this project is to create a database of the chemical properties of Arctic sedges and other plants known to dominate peatlands in the past. The database will be available to the public and be set up so that it can be easily updated and added to. The project will also continue a program that brings high school teachers from the New York area to the arctic to participate in field studies associated with the project. These teachers will then develop teaching modules connected to high school science curriculums. 

Members of the Cyperaceae (sedges) inhabit diverse environments, spanning a wide range of moisture balance, pH, and nutrient availability. However, they are notoriously difficult to identify by their fossil remains in peat cores, even to the family level, because of the paucity of identifiable plant parts that are species specific. But while the plant parts themselves are often absent, chemicals they produced are almost always present. Of the thousands of compounds produced, most have yet to be properly characterized and linked to particular species. This project will generate such a database and will also relate vegetation types, as characterized by their chemical constituents, to net carbon accumulation rate. In doing so, the first predictive models of carbon accumulation in peatlands based on vegetation change will be developed. This is an important step towards fully integrating peatlands into global climate models, which will allow a more comprehensive understanding of the feedbacks between climate change and peatland carbon accumulation.

por.por_cntn:
Peatlands, or wetland environments where plant growth exceeds plant decay, are an essential part of the global carbon cycle. Most peatland area is found in the Boreal and Arctic regions, where two plant communities  are common, one sphagnum moss-dominated, and the other sedge-dominated. Sphagnum-dominated peatlands are well studied, and the relationship of their ecology and carbon accumulation is relatively well understood. However, the ecology of sedge (family Cyperaceae) peatlands, which are no less common than sphagnum peatlands, is poorly understood, and the ecological, hydrological, and climatological parameters that influence the rate at which they accumulate carbon are also poorly understood. The major obstacle to understanding sedge peatlands and their relationship to the carbon cycle is our inability to distinguish among species within the Carex genus (family Cyperaceae) in fossil peatland core samples.  Carex fossils can primarily be distinguished by their fruits, and then to the species often only if the perigynium, or outer husk of the fruit, is present. Perigynia are too rarely preserved in sediment to meaningfully reconstruct past sedge-dominated environments to the species level. Without these reconstructions, we cannot build relationships between the ecology of modern Carex (the most diverse genus within Cyperaceae) and carbon accumulation. This project was aimed at developing methods of using fossil molecules from Carex to distinguish among different sedge taxa or groups of taxa and, in turn, generating continuous paleoecological reconstruction using those molecular tools.

 

Over the course of this project, we analyzed the concentrations of leaf wax compounds from hundreds of plants from the Arctic and Subarctic including scores of sedges in order to create a library of chemical profiles to distinguish the plants from each other in sediments. Using this library, we were able to distinguish between two common morphotypes of sedges—ones that create dense tussocks (called “cespitose”) and those with long or creeping rhizomes (“rhizomatous”). Using a network of core samples from throughout the Alaskan and far east Russian Arctic and Subarctic, we were also able to determine that sedge peatlands dominated by cespitose members of Cyperaceae accumulated much less carbon than those dominated by rhizomatous members of Cyperaceae. We further measured the concentration of redox-sensitive elements in the two types of peat sediments, and found that the slow-accumulating, cespitose-dominated sediments were much more likely to be oxic and prone to decay than the fast-accumulating rhizomatous-dominated sediments. This ability to discern biogeochemical and ecological differences between slow- and fast-accumulating sedge peatlands is a major advance in our understanding of the role of peatlands in the global carbon cycle.

 

During our review of the existing peatland literature in search of appropriate sites to include in our investigation, we came to an important realization. The amount of carbon currently assumed to be stored in Northern peatlands is vastly underestimated. Following up on this new hypothesis, we engaged in a deep survey of existing carbon accumulation data from peatlands and developed a new algorithm for calculating the total stock of carbon at high latitudes. Using the newly compiled data and new algorithm, we determined that it is likely to be approximately 1000 Gt of carbon stored in Northern peatlands—double previous estimates. While not in direct support of the project’s original goal, these new results provide extremely important context for the project’s main conclusions, and open many new lines of further inquiry.

 

In addition to the scientific accomplishments of the project, this work has had a strong impact on the Earth science community and Earth science education. This project supported a participant in Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory’s Visiting Arctic Science Teacher (VAST) program. A high school biology teacher participated in the project’s field work, and then incorporated her experiences in the field and the results of the project into her New York State Life Science curriculum. In addition to the benefit gained by the VAST teacher’s students, three undergraduates and ten high school students contributed in various ways to the success of the project. The three undergraduates all completed thesis-level projects based on their laboratory investigations, and one presented her results both at the Fall Meeting of the American Geophysical Union and the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.
